entry.title: Re: 在进行应收汇票的批量认领导入时，提示抵销科目的问题，提示未在公司代码中定义，请指教下，如何处理的
entry.content:
Hello @lemon-xue ,

Thank you for your question and follow-up

The error shows that Offsetting Account Determination is not active for your company's BoE receivable acceptance. In Public Cloud, setup explicitly includes defining versions for Offsetting Account Determination as part of the BoE configuration.  SAP Help Portal-Bill of Exchange Process Overview (CN)

Refer to below SAP KBA documentation below for possible solutions

3019897 – The Offsetting account cannot be determined in the document
It explains why the system cannot find an offsetting account and guides you to the necessary setup, including using Determine Offsetting Accounts Manually – China when automatic determination is not yet configured. SAP Support Portal-3019897 - Offsetting account cannot be determined in document&1&2&3

If you still encounter issues after setup or manual pairing, these two KBAs will assist with troubleshooting.

3461513 – How to manually determine offsetting accounts (step-by-step for the China apps). SAP Support Portal-3461513 - How to manually determine the offsetting accounts?

3461466 – After manual determination, the journal entry is still not in the cash flow (what you should check next). SAP Support Portal-3461466 - After manually determining the offsetting accounts, the journal entry still did not appear in the cash flow statements

For configuration, including activating and maintaining versions and rules, see SAP Help Configuring Offsetting Account Determination. SAP Help-Configuring Offsetting Account Determination

如需中文翻译或进一步支持，请随时告诉我。此致，敬礼

Chuma

entry.title: Re: SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025
entry.content:
Hi @BinWang 

Developer users do not need to be assigned to the IAS group j4a-admin.
Assigning the admin users to this j4a-admin group in IAS gives them access to the Maintain Certificate Mapping app, which is required to generate the one-time password (OTP) needed for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud system configuration ( please see above, step 8 )
Developers users need the SAP_BR_DEVELOPER role. 

Best,
Sebastian

entry.title: AI Lifecycle Through the Lens of ISO/IEC 42005:2025
entry.content:
Objective

Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming how organizations operate, from automation and predictive analytics to ethical decision-making. But as adoption scales, so do the risks like bias, lack of transparency, misuse, and unintended consequences. To address this, ISO has introduced a new AI standard: ISO/IEC 42005:2025, the first international AI System Impact Assessment (AIIA) framework.

As AI systems become more embedded in enterprise applications, the need for structured risk management, transparency, and lifecycle governance grows. The recently published ISO/IEC 42005 offers organizations a practical framework to manage AI system uncertainty, risk, and performance evaluation across their lifecycle.

In this blog, we will explore what is ISO 42005 and how it fits with the existing AI governance efforts like the AI Ethics and Risk Management Policy. We will also see how it can help make AI impact assessments more practical and useful in supporting to build a responsible AI Governance.

ISO/IEC 42005: AI System Impact Assessment (AIIA)

Purpose

ISO/IEC 42005 offers guidance on when and how to conduct AI Impact Assessments throughout the AI lifecycle from design to decommissioning.

This standard is a technical report designed to complement ISO/IEC 42001 (the AI Management System standard). While ISO 42001 sets up a high-level governance structure, ISO 42005 dives into operational AI management especially in areas like:

  • Uncertainty adaptation: Detect low confidence, escalate or fallback
  • Risk-based control mechanisms: Apply stricter controls for high-risk use cases
  • Performance evaluation over time: Monitor AI accuracy, retrain when needed
  • Defined decision rules & acceptance criteria: Document logic for when to trust or reject AI

In short, ISO 42005 helps answer this question:

“How do we make sure our AI behaves reliably, even in uncertain or high-risk conditions?”

Scope & Structure

The ISO 42005 standard:

  • Details a 10-step process: scoping, responsibility assignment, threshold definition, execution, analysis, documentation, oversight, monitoring, integration into risk systems, and review cycles.
  • Requires assessments across 9 impact dimensions: accountability, transparency, fairness, privacy, reliability, safety, explainability, environmental impact, and misuse/failure scenarios.
  • Aligns with regulatory frameworks like the EU AI Act.
  • Is compatible with broader governance systems like ISO/IEC 42001.
Key Features

Making Impact Assessment Core to AI Risk Management

One of the most powerful implications in ISO 42005 is that AI impact assessment should not be a onetime checkbox. It must be an ongoing, dynamic part of the AI lifecycle.

ISO 42005 puts importance on:

  • Evaluating uncertainty and risk in different stages of AI system lifecycle.
  • Linking performance expectations with decision logic and thresholds
  • Keeping the impact assessment alive across updates, retraining, and deployments
  • Engaging with Stakeholders (including affected communities, domain experts, and regulators).
  • Promoting integration with governance systems like ISO 42001.
  • Focusing on thorough documentation and auditability, including generation of evidence before deployment.
Adoption & Relevance

The ISO 42005 standard was officially published in June 2025, and it aligns closely with regulatory frameworks like the EU AI Act, where high‑risk AI systems require impact assessments.

Mapping of ISO/IEC 42005 with SAP AI Lifecycle

ISO/IEC 42005 – 10 Steps Process

Mapped SAP AI Lifecycle Phase

How It Translates in Practice

1. Scoping

Ideation

Define purpose, stakeholder needs, and ethical relevance. SAP uses checklists to classify risk.

2. Assigning responsibilities

Governance Integration (All Phases)

SAP assigns roles through the AI Ethics Steering Committee and domain leads.

3. Threshold definition

Validation

SAP identifies if AI use-case hits  “high-risk” criteria requiring deeper review.

4. Executing the impact assessment

Validation

SAP's handbook provides bias detection tools, fairness metrics, privacy impact templates, etc.

5.  Analysing findings

Validation

Governance team reviews flagged risks. Feedback loop to refine model, data, design.

6. Documenting and reporting

Realization

SAP mandates documentation of ethical rationale, decision logs, risk mitigations.

7. Oversight and decision-making

Validation → Productization

SAP Ethics Office or Committee either green lights, modifies, or blocks deployment.

8. Monitoring post-deployment

Operations

SAP monitors KPIs, model performance, feedback from users in real-world environments.

9. Integrating into risk management

All Phases via BAI AI System Governance

SAP feeds risk into enterprise-wide risk management (ERM)

10. Review and update cycle

Continuous Review (Quarterly/Annually)

SAP schedules periodic reviews and updates to models and ethics guidelines.

As noted above, SAP is already following the ISO 42005 recommendations.

The Way Forward: Steps to Operationalize ISO 42005

AI Assessment is commonly used as a checklist completed before product launch. At that point, all the big design choices have been made, the models trained, the contracts signed. The impact assessment becomes a retrospective step rather than a living tool to shape the product. We want to evolve this step to enable a continuous analysis and improvement of the AI functionalities throughout the development and test process.

With ISO 42005 impact assessment becomes an integral part of AI risk management and AI system lifecycle. 

The standard explicitly guides organizations on integrating AI impact assessment into existing AI risk management and AI management systems rather than treating it as an isolated task. It emphasizes performing assessments at appropriate times and coordinating with other existing processes like privacy or fundamental right impact assessments.

ISO 42005 doesn't require new processes. if you already have an AIIA or risk management framework, simply integrate its practices into your existing workflows.

Here are a few steps where ISO 42005 improves the lifecycle of AI development:

  • Integrate with Existing Risk Governance: Start by mapping out your current risk and quality processes (e.g. risk assessments, design reviews, compliance checks). For instance, add an “AI Impact” section to the template used for architectural reviews or product approval forms. This ensures discussions happen in the forums teams already know.
  • Adopt a Short but Precise AI Impact Checklist: Use a concise checklist (like SAP AI Impact Assessment Checklist) as the primary tool for AI impact assessment. Make it standard practice for every AI-related project to complete this checklist at kick-off and update it periodically. Host the checklist in your existing project documentation system so it’s visible and version controlled.
  • Embed Cross-Functional Review Early: Don’t isolate the impact assessment with one “AI Governance Steering Committee.” Instead, involve the project team and relevant domain experts (Security, Risk, DPMS etc.) in reviewing it. Early engagement of legal, compliance, and domain experts will catch issues and educate the project team on those considerations.
  • Use Tools for Efficiency: A lightweight approach can still use tools like automating parts of the assessment (like generating bias metrics) can integrate it further into the engineering workflow.
  • Ensure Leadership Support: Management must reinforce that this integrated impact assessment is not optional. There should be an integral part of AI governance. Any project with an unresolved red flag on the impact checklist must be approved by the Risk Committee before release.  
  • Continuously Improve the Process: Gather feedback from teams on the AI Impact Assessment checklist’s effectiveness. Maybe some questions seem irrelevant or new issues (like environmental impact or supply-chain ethics) need to be added as the field evolves. Update your process and templates in line with evolving standards (ISO 42005 will evolve too) and learnings from any incidents your organization experiences or observes in the industry.

ISO 42005 isn’t just a guideline but acts as a bridge between ethical intent and technical implementation.

The basic approach to conducting an AIIA is like an audit where you will need to gather and document information in line with each phase of the AI System Lifecycle assessment.  Unlike an audit, there is no need to gather evidence to support the assessment, which will make the process slightly easier.

entry.title: Re: Schema categories shows the blank Names and Descripti...
entry.content:
Hi Srinivas,

I can see from the Text File that the language is indicated as EN.
Without having access to the actual system, it's quite hard to analyze anything.
But:
Since the Schema has to exist before the import (empty shell), the logical conclusion would be, that the translation (the empty shell of it) also has to exist before the import.
Meaning, you probably have to somehow indicate that there's a second language in order for the import in another language to work. --> Maybe translate at least the root node.
However that's just my best guess.

Kind regards
Richard

entry.title: Error when trying to display APPS - Joule in SAP S/4HANA Public Edition
entry.content:
Hi everyone!

I’m currently using Joule inside SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, and when I ask Joule to show a Sales Order, I get the following error:

 

There are no intents, current user is authorized to (check BTP navigation service is up-to-date),
Source: GET, /navigation/api/v2/inbounds?pageSize=1000000,
user 'user@email.com', semantic object type 'salesOrder'.
 OBS: Generic Email for security

The Manage Sales Orders app appears and works normally in the SAP Fiori Launchpad, so the app itself is available.
It seems the issue is that Joule cannot find the intent or inbound for the salesOrder semantic object.

I also tried accessing /navigation/api/v2/inbounds, but received the following response:

403 Forbidden - The request has been blocked by UCON.

I’d like to understand if anyone has faced a similar issue.current limitations of Joule integration in S/4HANA Public Edition?

Any insights, suggestions, or experiences would be greatly appreciated 🙏

entry.title: Re: Page Map error
entry.content:
Hello,

I was able to fix it on my side. In my manifest.json, under dataSources, I have "localUri" entries that are used by Page Map.

One of the XML files was not in my localService folder (the service annotation file ***_ANNO_MDL.xml).

I downloaded it from the backend and placed it in the localService folder. After that, I was able to open Page Map.

For your information, the error was displayed in the Output section (near Terminal) for SAP Fiori tools – Application Modeler.

Best regards,

Severin

entry.title: Re: Determining freight costs in the STO transfer process
entry.content:
It seems like requirement is to capture cost on material valuation for STO. This is a standard functionality. Add a cost condition in STO pricing schema. Cost will be distributed based on weight. Material valuation should be active. Refer below link for details:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/sto-freight-cost-loaded-on-material-cost/qaq-p/11837754

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/sto-pricing-procedure/qaq-p/7974940

In case you are using transportation module which does freight cost calculation and posting to ERP, then this requirement can be handle in Transportation module.

entry.title: Re: Wireshark with SAP Dissectors for Ubuntu and macOS
entry.content:
Seems this blog is nowadays "read-only" even for its author (me), maybe due to the change of blog-toolset in SAP Community site in early 2024, I don't know. Anyway, here is some additional information from when I was recently setting up the SAP Dissectors for Wireshark in MacBook case...

Port Numbers

If in the Preferences pane of Wireshark you are offered the chance to modify the port numbers each SAP Dissector applies for, then you would make the modifications according to your needs. For example, in Wireshark for MacBook, I changed the values for the SAP Dissectors as follows: 

SAPDIAG to 3200-3299 (instead of just 3200); SAPMS to 3600,3601,3900 (added in 3601); SAPNI to 3200-3299,40000 (instead of just 3200,40000); SAPRFC to 3300-3399 (instead of just 3300 or just 3301, whatever was initially there). Once you have changed the port numbers to suit, press OK to close the Preferences windows, this will save your changes.

 

Additional commands for MacBook M-series

After using brew to install qt5, it is a good idea to copy the suggested commands in the output info and run those. For example I got this info in Terminal:

If you need to have qt@5 first in your PATH, run:

echo 'export PATH="/opt/homebrew/opt/qt@5/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find qt@5 you may need to set:

export LDFLAGS="-L/opt/homebrew/opt/qt@5/lib"

export CPPFLAGS="-I/opt/homebrew/opt/qt@5/include"

For cmake to find qt@5 you may need to set:

export CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH="/opt/homebrew/opt/qt@5"

By running these, you avoid errors more easily when e.g. using the 'cmake' command. [Note that if you are using a different shell than zsh, it would be up to you to modify the first export command appropriately].

 

Additional commands for Intel MacBooks

The corresponding extra commands on older Intel MacBooks would be something like the following:

If you need to have qt@5 first in your PATH, run:

echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/qt@5/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find qt@5 you may need to set:

export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/qt@5/lib"

export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/qt@5/include"

For cmake to find qt@5 you may need to set:

export CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH="/usr/local/opt/qt@5"

entry.title: Unable to deploy application with cdm.json – 404 errors in Build Work Zone
entry.content:
Hello,

Our project involves deploying a Fiori/UI5 application and its associated library to the BTP subaccount DEV_TAL (region: Europe Netherlands – eu20), where deployments through BAS and Cloud Foundry normally succeed without errors. We are encountering persistent issues when attempting to migrate deployment of our application through a cdm.json in SAP Build Work Zone.

When deploying from SAP Business Application Studio via Cloud Foundry (mbt build > cf deploy app.mtar), the process works as expected: the application appears in the HTML5 Applications repository, can be managed in the Content Manager, and finally runs correctly when exposed in a site.

The difficulties arise specifically when switching to a CDM-based deployment. Our goal is to automate group and role creation and ensure consistent provisioning of application tiles. For testing, we are deploying a minimal MTA consisting of one application and one library. After setting up the CDM and RT destinations, creating the content provider, and assigning the required roles to both user and site, the tile appears correctly in Build Work Zone.

However, once launched, the application fails to load properly: in the HTML5 Applications repository, the application runs without errors – the database not being connected is normal at this point. In Build Work Zone, the tile opens but the application immediately crashes with a flurry of 404 errors. As a result, the application does not boot at all, and the intended library resources remain inaccessible.

We have followed the official tutorial Designing UI5 Apps as Business Solution for SAP Build Work Zone and reproduced its GitHub template, but the outcome remains the same. The issue appears to be tied to the CDM integration and how the application accesses its library and resources once deployed in Build Work Zone.

 

 

 

Environment

  • Subaccount: DEV_TAL
  • Subdomain: dev-tal-ks9oev3t
  • Subaccount ID: 8b106794-ec42-4ee1-bacf-a039900b13cb
  • Tenant ID: 8b106794-ec42-4ee1-bacf-a039900b13cb
  • Org Name (CF): ARGONandCO_dev-tal-ks9oev3t
  • Org ID (CF): cafe0aa6-6373-455c-9dd1-f52e2e435364
  • Region: Europe (Netherlands) – eu20
  • API Endpoint: https://api.cf.eu20-001.hana.ondemand.com
  • Space: dev

 

Reproduction Steps

  1. Run mbt to generate .mtar.
  2. Deploy via cf deploy app.mtar.
  3. Application appears in HTML5 Applications repository in cockpit.
  4. Create a Content Provider using both cdm and rt destinations
  5. Add role to both User and website
  6. Tile appears in BWZ.
  7. Launch the tile.

 

Observed Behavior

  • Tile name appears correctly in BWZ.
  • In the HTML5 Applications repository: application launches with its library
  • In the BWZ: application crashes and shows numerous 404 errors appear in the console.
  • Application does not boot.

 

Expected Behavior

  • Application should launch without errors.
  • Library should be available, and components should load.
  • Groups and roles should be automatically created by CDM.

 

Tests Performed

  • Added and removed the cap-ui prefix to all destinations: no effect, 404 errors persist.
  • Changed _schema-version between "3.1" and "3.2" and the the library path from "/cap-ui.argonuilib-1.0.0" to "/cap-ui.argonuilib", as per the template: no effect, same errors observed.

 

Attachments

  • cdm.json
  • mta.yaml
  • screenshots from BWZ and HTML5 error logs
  • manifests of both application and library
  • index.html of the application

 

References

  • Tutorial followed: Designing UI5 Apps as Business Solution for SAP Bu... - SAP Community (GitHub template reproduced).

 

Request

  • Confirm whether additional tenant-specific configuration (e.g. contentProvider mapping) is required.
  • Clarify which files are critical in CDM deployment that could block the process (mta.yaml, cdm.json, manifest.json, xs-app.json, ui5.yaml…).
  • Clarify the pathing necessary to and from the library from the application (e.g. resourceRoots in manifest.json, data-sap-ui-resourceroots in index.html, etc.).
  • Clarify where and when the sap.cloud.service should be attached to destinations

entry.title: Re: MIRO transaction PO details is not showing
entry.content:
Hi,
If you're not seeing PO details in the MIRO transaction screen in SAP, here are a few common causes and troubleshooting steps you can try:

Please find the possible reasons and fixes

Missing Goods Receipt (GR):
If the PO is for materials, ensure the GR has been posted. Use transaction MB51 or ME2N to verify GR status.

Service PO without Entry Sheet:
For service POs, you must create a Service Entry Sheet using ML81N before MIRO. Without it, the PO details won't appear.

Incorrect Item Category or Account Assignment:
If the PO uses item category "F" (for services) or has account assignment, ensure all required fields are correctly filled and posted.

User-Specific Authorization Issues:
Sometimes, PO details show for one user but not another. This could be due to missing roles or authorization objects. Compare user roles and authorizations

entry.title: Re: How to run "local" tRFC via bgRFC? (local: with no destination or 'NONE')
entry.content:
Hey Sandra, is there a reason you're specifically trying to use an `OUTBOUND` destination here? I think, since you're trying to go for a similar behavior as `NONE` you could make use of the default `INBOUND` destination instead(?).

See also: https://help.sap.com/docs/abap-cloud/abap-concepts/creating-default-destination-bgpf

Either as the link (above) says using the name `BGPF` or literally `DEFAULT`, depending on the system you're on I'd say.

Our on-prem sandbox has both configured ...

Maybe that helps, though, I will see what other opinions are here. 🙂

BR, Marco

entry.title: Re: Error in WORK CENTER POD as index =0 when using the P...

entry.title: Re: Correct config to release returned stock from Blocked...
entry.content:
Hello @SAPSupport 

The system is blocking the manual moving from Blocked to Unrestricted because the stock is still flagged for returns inspection. In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, customer return inspections are managed within the warehouse process, which is why a traditional QM lot would appear in QA32. Instead, record and complete the inspection via Enter Inspection Results from Warehouse. SAP Help Portal-Enter Inspection Results - From Warehouse

To release stock, open Enter Inspection Results from Warehouse (MSR_INSPWH) for the return, record results, set Logistical Follow-Up Activity to 0011 (Transfer to Free Stock), then Save and Confirm. This post stocks to Unrestricted and clears the inspection reference. Using 0031 (No further activities) won't create a posting change and leaves the stock blocked under inspection.  SAP Help Portal-Logistical Follow-Up Activities

  • What you should do?
  • App: Enter Inspection Results – From Warehouse (MSR_INSPWH). This is the warehouse inspection app you need for customer returns

Process Inspection Lots — App ID: (launchpad). Note that the official name uses the plural form.

Follow-up activity: 0011 – Transfer to Free Available Stock. SAP Help Portal-Logistical Follow-Up Activities

Let me know if you need further assistance

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: flow control between exception sub process and main flow: SAP CPI-IS
entry.content: The pictures are not clear Sugata. Does your main flow have an exception handler? Also iFlow exception process does not mimic the traditional way of try/catch blocks. Ending the exception block with "End Message" and setting the flow status to true before that, may be nullifying it. Needs a detailed look into it!

entry.title: How to automatically create an Email Interaction via Workflow Rule in SAP Sales Cloud (C4C)?
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I’m currently working on a requirement in SAP Sales Cloud (C4C) related to Ticket Interactions, and I would appreciate your help to clarify the correct configuration steps.

 

Business scenario

When a new ticket is created in C4C, I need an automatic email to be sent to the customer (either Individual Customer or Account contact) depending on the value in the "Incident Category ID" field and "Ticket Type" field

Additionally, this email interaction should appear under the Interactions tab of the ticket — the same way as manually sent or received emails are displayed.

What I’ve done so far

  1. I created a Workflow Rule for the Ticket  Business Object (Timing = On create only; Rule Type=E-mail)

  2. The rule is triggered On Create when Incident Category ID= “X” and Ticket Type = "X"

  3. As an action, I selected E-mail and uploaded an HTML file via the Template File field.

  4. Recipient Determination: Contact of Account or Individual Account for Ticket

However:

  • The workflow sends no email (or I can’t confirm if it does).

  • No Interaction record appears in the Interactions tab of the ticket.

Thanks a lot in advance for any guidance or documentation links — I’ve already checked the SAP Help Portal and Community posts about workflow rules and ticket interactions, but I couldn’t find an end-to-end example of this scenario.

I’d also appreciate any insights on whether there are additional configuration steps related to the Email Activity that I might be missing.

Best regards,

entry.title: Integration Advisor: Early UN/EDIFACT Versions with Syntax Version 2 Now Available
entry.content:
Today, I would like to share an update regarding the B2B Library versions included in our Integration Advisor (of SAP Integration Suite) offering. Recently, we added three additional UN/EDIFACT versions from the early 1990s. 

Early Versions of the UN/EDIFACT standard

We have added three additional early versions: 90.2 S2, 91.1 S2 and 91.2 S2 – bringing the total number of supported UN/EDIFACT versions to 63.

To the best of our knowledge, even older versions (particularly 90.1 S1) are not in productive use. However, please contact us if you require this S1 version, and we will evaluate whether it can be added.

Interoperability of Syntax Version 2 (S2) and Syntax Version 3 (S3)

UN/EDIFACT syntax versions (defined by ISO 9735) are sets of rules specifying the structure of EDIFACT messages. To date, four syntax versions have been published by the UN/ECE organization: S1, S2, S3, and S4.  

These syntax versions are, in a way, orthogonal to the UN/EDIFACT versions / releases (such as 91.2 or D.01B). However, it is common practice to display UN/EDIFACT versions alongside the syntax version that was in use at the time the UN/EDIFACT version was published (e.g., 91.2 S2 or D.01B S3).

Accordingly, Integration Advisor displays all previously published UN/EDIFACT versions with the suffix S3, while the recently added versions are shown with the suffix S2.

It is important to note that syntax versions 2 and 3 are almost identical, differing only in the allowed code pages (UNOA-UNOB for S2 versus UNOA-UNOF for S3) defined in data element UNB > S001 > 0001.

This is why you can also use later UN/EDIFACT versions with syntax version 2 or use earlier UN/EDIFACT versions with syntax version 3.  

Code Values for syntax-related Data Elements  

The UN/EDIFACT standard includes certain core data elements, typically named 00**, which are used in service segments such as UNB, UNG, UNH, UNT, or UNZ. Originally, the UN/ECE organization did not provide code values for some of these core data elements and only began doing so in the mid-1990s.

Integration Advisor strives to publish B2B Library definitions as provided by the standardization organizations. As a result, the recently added UN/EDIFACT versions do not include code values for data elements 0002, 0052, or 0054.

Handling of Code Values associated with UN/CEFACT codelists

Since 1991, UN/ECE has recommended using UN/CEFACT codelists for certain UN/EDIFACT data elements. The table below lists the affected data elements along with their assigned UN/CEFACT codelists: 

Data ElementDescriptionUN/EDIFACT CodelistUN/CEFACT Codelist
4053Delivery or transport terms4053Rec 5
4277Payment terms4277Rec 17
4405Transport status4405Rec 24
6411Measurement units6411Rec 20 
7065Package types7065Rec 21
8023Freight and charges identification8023Rec 23
8067Transport modes8067Rec 19
8179Transport means8179Rec 28

Accordingly, Integration Advisor provides links from these data elements to the latest version of the listed UN/CEFACT recommendations. This applies to all versions of UN/EDIFACT starting from 91.1 S2. (Please note that the UN/EDIFACT standard did not maintain any code values for these data elements in the earlier version 90.2 S2.)

For versions 91.1 S2 and 91.2 S2, we also provide UN/EDIFACT codelists containing the code values as they were originally published by the UN/EDIFACT standard. In your Message Implementation Guideline (MIG), you have the option to use either the original UN/EDIFACT code values or the current UN/CEFACT code values.  

Consumption in Cloud Integration  

Since earlier this year, the Cloud Integration capability of SAP Integration Suite has supported all UN/EDIFACT syntax versions (S1 through S4). This means you can process UN/EDIFACT payloads in all the EDI flow steps, such as EDI Splitter, EDI Extractor, EDI-To-XML Converter, and XML-To-EDI Converter, based on all these syntax versions. 

Note: You need to use the latest version of these EDI flow steps. In your Integration Flow, simply add the EDI flow steps from the palette to ensure you are using the newest version.

For the older UN/EDIFACT versions, there is one additional detail to note: 

  • Since release D.93A S3 in 1993, UN/EDIFACT has used the value D for field UNH > S009 > 0052. As a result, the EDI flow steps expect an XSD file name like UN-EDIFACT_ORDERS_D96A.xsd.
  • However, for releases prior to D.93A S3, other values (such as 1 or 2) were used for field UNH > S009 > 0052. In these cases, the EDI flow steps expect an XSD file name like UN-EDIFACT_ORDERS_2912.xsd.

Integration Advisor has recently added a new field Configure EDIFACT Message Version to tab Runtime Context (of your MIG) where this value can be maintained - see the screenshot below.   

When you create a new Message Implementation Guideline (MIG), Integration Advisor automatically selects an appropriate default value based on the following rules: 

  • Use D as the default value for all UN/EDIFACT versions starting with D (from D.93A onwards) 
  • Use 1 as the default value for all UN/EDIFACT versions not starting with D and having a minor version of 1 (applies to versions 91.1 S2 and 92.1 S3) 
  • Use 2 as the default value for all UN/EDIFACT versions not starting with D and having a minor version of 2 (applies to versions 90.2 S2, 91.2 S2, and 93.2 S3) 

In most cases, the default value should meet your requirements. If not, you can easily redefine this value in your MIG.

Conclusion

With this latest update, Integration Advisor has added three early UN/EDIFACT versions associated with Syntax Version 2. This enables you to build your Message Implementation Guidelines (MIGs) and Mapping Guidelines (MAGs) based on these S2 versions.

Further reading

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/overview-of-b2b-standards 

https://blogs.sap.com/2021/09/28/integration-advisor-overview-of-components-for-building-b2b-integra...
https://blogs.sap.com/2018/07/13/integration-content-advisor-create-a-customized-interface-using-mig...

entry.title: Re: KSS2-assign splitting structure ERROR： Client 100 has status 'not modifiable' Message no. TK4
entry.content: You’ll usually see that “Client 100 has status ‘not modifiable’ (TK430)” message when trying to make config-level changes in a client set as Production or No Changes allowed. If you can’t adjust SCC4, one workaround is to perform the assignment in a customizing client, then transport the change into Client 100. Alternatively, check if you can use SM30 → V_TKA09 (depending on authorizations) to adjust splitting structure assignments indirectly. Also make sure you’re not in a cross-client table when doing it — that’s often why the modifiability restriction triggers.

entry.title: Re: Gathering both Machine and labor time from APO (PA3)
entry.content:
Good day @petrocsek 

Thank you for your question.

To summarise, it is standard that only the scheduling relevant capacity is transferred from ERP work center when integrating APO. Labour time is not transferred automatically. However, you consider the following options:

  • First is to use custom enhancement to capture and store labour time during your CIF transfer.
  • Second option is to model dual resources (machine and Labour) and activate secondary resource transfer in CIF customising.

Alternatively, potential simpler way is for you to maintain labour vs. Machine time reporting directly in ERP through the BW extractors.

Have you had a look at the references for more details.

 How Are the Details of the Order Mapped in SAP APO and SAP R/3?

Integration of Resources

https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-q-a/pooled-capacity-in-apo/qaq-p/9901760

 Let me know if you have any questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: What exactly is SAP BW PCE… and what it is not !
entry.content:
Hello Mel,

Your existing BW 7.5 PCE deployment in US20 can stay where it is, regardless where the public cloud components of BDC are deployed. That's because there's no co-location requirement for the private and public component services.

Your SAP sales team can help you restructure your existing contract to fit the BW landscape under the BDC commercial umbrella and with that, you'd have access to the Data Product Generator. In addition,  you can plan for a reduction of the BW landscape (aka scale-down) , free up the BW-dedicated capacity units, and then use them for the public cloud component services.

I hope this helps,
Karsten

entry.title: Value Help as dropdown, not F4 in Custom Fields - Code List
entry.content:
Hello, 

the topic is about implementing a Custom Field via KeyUser Extensions. 

I was wondering is there anyway to change the standard behavior of displaying the Value Help for the Custom Field based on Code List. The default scenario is the Value Help opens up:

My question is - can it be changed to the dropdown list (Like in the Status field in screenshot)? In the documentation I see that it should be automatically be done as Dropdown when the data set is small - I have only 7 values. But it appears as a F4 Value Help. 

Of course I can create a CDS based Code List - and then manually set the @ObjectModel.resultSet.sizeCategory: #XS. But in the regular Code List you cannot edit ABAP files. And for e.g. for Custom Fields with 3-4 values I don't want to have to create an additional table, text table for translations, value help CDS, and then the Custom Fields. 

Any solutions to that?

entry.title: Re: Cracking the “!” Mystery in SAP on Sybase ASE: Why isql Rejects Your Password
entry.content:
You're still not out of the woods.

In unix/linux shells (eg, bash, ksh) , if the password contains a dollar sign ($) and is either a) not wrapped in quotes or b) is wrapped in double quotes then the $ is treated by the shell as an indicator of a (shell) variable reference.

Consider:

$ echo 123$x456
123

$ echo "123$x456"
123

$ echo '123$x456'
123$x456

$ echo 123$456
12356

$ echo "123$456"
12356

$ echo '123$456'
123$456

In the 1st and 2nd cases (no quotes, double quotes) the shell thinks $x456 is a variable reference and  since (in this case) there is no variable named x456 the shell replaces $x456 with an empty string (ie, nothing) so the echo only sees 123.

In the 3rd case (single quotes) the shell makes no attempt to interpret the contents (within the single quotes) so the $ is treated as a literal character and the echo sees the entire string.

In the 4th and 5th cases (no quotes, double quotes) the $4 is treated by the shell as a reference to the 4th input parameter to the script; assuming there is no 4th input parameter the shell replaces $4 with an empty string (ie, nothing) so the echo sees 12356.

In the 6th case (single quotes) the shell makes no attempt to interpret the contents (within the single quotes) so the $ is treated as a literal character and the echo sees the entire string 123$456.

------------------

Net result:

  • several of the characters listed as Valid special character have special meaning to unix/linux shells; single quotes should disable the (unix/linux) shell's attempts to interpret said characters
  • only one set of (single) quotes is necessary so ...
  • in the isql/password example it should be sufficient to use -P 'a!terpwd123'
  • NOTE: for an embedded single quote (also a Valid special character !!) switching to double quotes would be one solution, eg, "sample'string", 'sample'"'"'string' - in the 2nd case the middle '"'"' is a single quote (match leading single quote) plus "  '  " (wrap single quote in double quote) plus single quote (match trailing single quote)

entry.title: Re: Miro enhancement
entry.content:
Structure ACCIT_SUB can be enhanced by append.

  • Check the call of the methods, there is a MOVE-CORRESPONDING after the call.
  • Insure any other implementation will not clear this field, so should copy it from import parameters

entry.title: Re: Simplifying PM Task List Migration: Iterative Loading of Operations and Suboperations
entry.content:
Great contribution.

Please, could you also provide more details about the modifications to the LTMOM so that it works when the Maintenance Packages and Components fields are filled out?

When I tested the template, the sub-operations only work correctly when the Header and Operations tabs are filled out, but when using the Packages and/or Components tabs, I get errors.

entry.title: Re: Welcome to the Future: The 2H 2025 Home Page Redesign in SuccessFactors
entry.content:
https://community.sap.com/t5/product-and-customer-updates/exciting-updates-are-coming-to-your-sap-successfactors-home-page/bc-p/14243832/highlight/true#M20597 

I just saw this update on another post - adding here for the others that were looking for the Quick Action labels like I was:

"The quick action labels are a late-breaking enhancement to the home page that we're adding in an update later this month. So they're already visible in some demo environments you might have seen, and they'll make it to your environments before the 2H production release."
